isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - CAB - TILT: 9600 AND 9700 SLEEPER AND NON-SLEEPER CABS - SHEET METAL REPAIRS - TYPES OF PANEL FASTENERS (RIVETS)

svcprocinfo.para: Three basic types of panel fasteners are used for repairs. Descriptions and other information on these follow.

svcsubproc.title: "Cherry G" Rivet
svcsubproc.para: On certain specified locations, a variation of the 1/4 inch (6.35 mm) or 3/16 inch (4.76 mm) blind rivet called a "Cherry G" rivet must be used. It is installed with rivet tool and nosepiece used for Monobolts from Cherry Commercial Fastener ( Figure 55).

svcsubproc.title: Monobolt
svcsubproc.para: This one piece fastener ( Figure 53) has a grooved stem or mandrel and has a skirted tail. It is used where access is available on one side of material only. Use same rivet tool and nosepiece used with "Cherry G" rivets.
A typical installation cycle is covered in the steps below and shown in Figure 56.

step1.para: Insert Monobolt mandrel into installing tool nosepiece and place Monobolt skirt end in panels to be joined (A).
Activate tool to exert pulling force on mandrel. As pulling force continues, a blind head begins to form against back side of panels (B).
Continue pulling clamp panels firmly together. Nosepiece stakes locking skirt of mandrel into recess in Monobolt head. Mandrel breaks flush with Monobolt head (C).

svcsubproc.title: Lockbolt
svcsubproc.para: This two-piece fastener ( Figure 52) consists of a pin or head half and collar. It is used where there is access to both sides of the pieces being fastened.

figure.caption: Figure 56. Details of a Lockbolt Fastener

svcsubproc.para: A typical installation cycle is covered in steps below and shown in Figure 57.

calloutgroup.callout1: A. COLLAR OVER LOCKBOLT PIN TAIL
C. FORMING LOCK BETWEEN COLLAR AND LOCKBOLTS

step1.para: Insert pin from one side of work (A) through prepared hole. Collar is then placed over the pin tail on opposite side.
When Lockbolt tool nose is applied (B), chuck jaws grip pull grooves. Tool pulls on pin and starts drawing panels together.
As the pull on pin increases, tool anvil swages collar into locking grooves and a permanent lock is formed (C).
The tool will then continue to pull until pin breaks at breakneck groove and is ejected. Tool anvil will then disengage from swaged collar (D).
